awd_titl_txt: NSF Postdoctoral Fellowship in Biology FY 2021: Fluid homeostasis in the evolution of frog breeding phenology
awd_abstract_narration:
This action funds an NSF Postdoctoral Research Fellowship in Biology for FY 2021, Broadening Participation of Groups Underrepresented in Biology. The Fellowship supports a research and training plan for the Fellow that will increase the participation of groups underrepresented in biology. The goal of this research is to understand the role of aquaporin proteins in allowing frogs to overcome harsh environments, and how this may be related to climate and breeding behaviors. Aquaporins allow water to move across cell membranes and therefore allow frogs to maintain water balance in many different environments. Frogs might encounter harsh weather conditions during their reproductive period and must overcome them in order to reproduce and survive. The Fellow will obtain data on the genetic diversity of aquaporins and other relevant traits from various species of frogs living in different habitats. Laboratory experiments will be used to determine how different species may adapt to hot, cold, or dry conditions and eventually inform amphibian conservation efforts. If differences across species are observed, it is implied that aquaporins are important in allowing frogs to survive changing climates and are related to breeding behaviors in frogs. Additionally, the Fellow will design and implement free public workshops for graduate students providing practical guides for reporting statistical results and enhancing scientific reproducibility, with the goal of promoting the participation of historically underrepresented groups at the postdoctoral level.

This research will test three hypotheses to determine the evolutionary relationship between behavior, climate, and genetic and functional diversity in aquaporin proteins: H1) breeding period duration across anurans is related to climate, H2) diversity in aquaporin sequences is influenced by climate, and H3) aquaporin gene expression is related to temperature/water availability. H1 and H2 will be analyzed using phylogenetic generalized least squares (PGLS) regression while accounting for relevant traits such as body size or habitat preference. For H2, pairwise genetic distances will be obtained via generalized time-reversible models and then projected into a Euclidean space (required for PGLS regression) using multidimensional scaling. H3 will be analyzed using a phylogenetic multivariate analysis of variance model. It is expected that temperature will be one of the major factors influencing sequence diversity, gene expression, and breeding period duration. This research is important for understanding past biogeography and future conservation prospects in anurans. Training objectives for the Fellow include developing mentorship skills and learning to obtain and analyze data on climate, molecular sequences, and gene expression.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
My research has resulted in significant scientific advancement of our understanding of where and why amphibians live and reproduce across different environments. As part of these this research grant, I have collaborated with students, faculty, and staff across 4 different instutitions in the United States. Together, we have found how different environmental factors together with anatomy may influence when and where frogs choose to breed. Additionally, we have found the rates at which 3 different species of frogs dehydrate across a variety of different habitats. Together, these results tell us about the significance of environmental variables in controlling where (amphibian) species live and breed. The novel contribution of these studies is that we identified that reproductive behaviors and dehydration rates sometimes show unforeseen responses to climate or environmental conditions. These unforeseen responses depend on specific combinations of temperature and water availability, but also depend on where the species live since tropical frogs sometimes showed inverse relationships relative to frogs living closer to the poles of the Earth. Through these collaborations I have trained mentees and received mentorship myself in various kinds of statistical data analysis and learned new methodologies used to collect genetic, climate, and biogeographical data. Currently, we have published 1 study that was supported by this grant, a second study is in the peer-review process, and 4 other projects are currently being prepared for submission to peer-reviewed scientific journals. 

This research has offered me the opportunity to have a broad national impact on STEM students interested in pursuing careers in science, specifically as future postdoctoral scholars. Participating in this research also allowed me to attend 5 difference scientific conferences, a prestigious and selective leadership workshop (through the National Diversity in STEM conference), and communicate my research to other scientists at many other universities. Under the Broader Impacts guidance of the NSF, I discussed the importance of broadening the participation of various groups in science and enhancing the participation of these students at the postdoctoral level. This resulted in an invitation to formalize these ideas in a journal outside the (biology) fields of my collaborators and myself. Furthermore, outside of the research supported by this grant, I also participated in several other opportunities to support the intellectual and career development of undergraduates, PhD students, and postdocs at the national and international levels. I accomplished this by securing funding for teaching 4 mentoring or data science workshops, 1 data science class at Stanford University, and participating in mentorship events at each conference I went to. Additionally, I obtained funding to bring historically underrepresented scientists at various levels in their career to a scientific symposium where we will discuss the importance of water flow in biology, but also the importance of our identities as scientists in the science that we do. Overall, my outreach activities have resulted in unique mentorship experience for students, various opportunities for students to learn practical and technical skills associated with data science and analysis, provided a spaces for scientists at all levels to network and collaborate, and the importance of my research has had impact across colleges and universities in the United States and internationally. 


Last Modified: 11/28/2023
Modified by: Bryan H Juarez
